issues.title: attribute 99 example
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
From Stephane Bortzmeyer:
> May be adding a mention of the "attribute 99" debacle? That was a good
case of a legal value breaking implementations that were not expecting
it.

https://labs.ripe.net/Members/erik/ripe-ncc-and-duke-university-bgp-experiment/
http://ccie-in-3-months.blogspot.kr/2010/08/decoding-ripe-experiment.html

issues.title: Need some examples from lower layers
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: #3 might work, though Brian has volunteered to provide text, which is even better.

comments.author: britram
comments.body: please assign this to me so I won't forget it :)

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: You'll have to accept the invite I just sent you first.

issues.title: Mention invariants
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: ...and their interaction with greasing. Invariants are the properties of the protocol that you don't want to protect.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: The interaction with greasing is a complementary one.  And both assume a very particular threat model.  The goal is not to defend against a motivated adversary, but to help those that aim to implement the protocol faithfully.  For greasing, there is an active mechanism that provides gentle encouragement to do the right thing; for invariants, the goal is more modest.  Invariants aim to clearly document those pieces of the protocol that are *intentionally ossified into the design*, as opposed to those things are are merely exposed to ossification.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: @britram, @mirjak, do you have anything to add here?

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: One question that I had was if we maybe should use the term greasing a bit more generic than "just" a specific technique as used by TLS. For me defining invariants, by saying these bits are fixed, also means that you need to make sure that all other bits vary (randomly) and could not be ossified accidentally. That's a bit stronger than just complementing each other, as you say above. I would even say that you need one for the other: if you define invariants, you must think about greasing/flexibility of everything else. Does that make sense?

issues.title: Look for older examples of greasing
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: Ted suggests that while the name is new, the practice probably isn't.  Send an email to architecture-discuss asking for examples of this sort of thing in the past.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: This discussion didn't turn up much.  It seems like there is a case to be made here that greasing is a new technique.

issues.title: Back claims more
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
From Stephen Farrell:

> There are a bunch of assertions in the draft that
may or may not be true but that are asserted as if
they are true. I would bet that a bunch of 'em are
true but don't see sufficient evidence given or cited.
To take the earliest example: "Protocols can react
to these shifts in one of three ways: adjust usage
patterns within the constraints of the protocol,
extend the protocol, and replace the protocol." Well,
first off, protocols don't react, chemicals and
living things do:-) But assuming you mean some class
of person, I at least can ignore the hell out of
many many things as another option. So this doesn't
seem to be a correct analysis of the options. I
think there are a good few examples like this and
that those add up to too many to be sure how they
may affect the overall argument.

First step: collect the instances where this class of error might appear.  Then perform some analysis.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: EDM discussion: document has been re-worked and clarified, good to re-review

issues.title: BGP example
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: Jeff seemed to suggest that experience with BGP might provide some useful insights.

issues.title: Consider describing RTP/RTCP muxing thing
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: Reclamation of code points here was eventually successful.  Might talk to some mmusic folks about the history there.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: SDP also provides great examples of ossified fields.  Consider the RTP/AVP RTP/SAVP RTP/AVPF RTP/SAVPF mess.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: EDM discussion: OK to close this one

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: "SDP is great example of ossification onto a really terrible design."

issues.title: Grease suggestions and motivations
issues.author: hardaker
issues.body:
The way the grease section ends leaves it unclear in my mind whether it's being a recommended solution or not.  It feels concluded (and maybe it's just informational, but then stating explicitly that there are pros/cons with this mechanism may help state explicitly that there isn't a conclusion being offered).

It's also unclear why someone would be motivated to actually implement grease at all; what is the gain by doing so unless you're a security scanner?  Why would the average implementation do something like this?  What's their motivation that justifies an increase in complexity (which you specifically point out doesn't happen in typical engineering in "Good Protocol Design is Not Sufficient")?

comments.author: hardaker
comments.body: I like the new text.  But it still doesn't explain what would motivate the average implementation for actually putting the work in (only to actually decrease interoperability temporarily).  In other portions of the document we already state implementors are lazy or trying to push new code quickly, and this is a cost in both $$s, speed and interoperability.  I'm glad it worked for TLS, but what motivated people to do it?  Or was that "things had gotten so bad we have to do something"; it certainly wasn't at the start of the protocol, ie.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Doesn't it say that it is done to protect the ability to deploy new extensions in future?  Sure, that's not always a pressing concern, but that depends on how acutely you have felt the pain of not being able to ship an extension.

comments.author: hardaker
comments.body: What market forces are motivated to implement and deploy it?  Logically, I understand why it's useful.  I understand less why real-world folks would be willing to take the time and energy to do implement it.  IE, theory: understood.  Practical: I don't see motivation for software writers that could be justified to management easily.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
I don't think that this is justified on such simple or direct terms.  You probably have to look to the concept of merit goods if you want to get into economics here.  After all, the benefit is not necessarily something that the implementer sees, it's one that the community as a whole sees (or might see) in the fullness of time.

After all, if you couch a question about deploying encryption in the same way, you might have similar trouble in justification.  The answer is usually tied into hedging strategies against the risk of future problems.  

For example, you might reasonably say that making cleartext DNS queries in most networks is benign.  And the cost of deploying encryption is considerable. More so if you start with the understanding that most network operators accord those requests with due respect, including taking every effort to ensure that they are the only ones that see those packets.  If you consider the breadth of possible networks and the span of time, the occasional instances of failures in that regard might lead to a different risk assessment.

Collectively, the QUIC working group has expended significant energy on this general question.  This is in part because of a deeper understanding of the risk profile in that environment.  This stuff really does happen.  I don't know if I recounted the story about Google's QUIC breaking a few years ago due to bad assumptions made about the semantics of a key protocol element.  Add the scars from multiple bad experiences with TLS and you might appreciate that there is some desire to address the problem proactively.

Of course, even with the desire to protect future extensibility, there is some justified skepticism about the efficacy of greasing as a general mechanism.  I hope that this document has captured that.

issues.title: Jari's comments
issues.author: martinthomson

comments.author: jariarkko
comments.body: I left a comment in IAB-email about some suggestions on what to do.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: A reponse was given there, including several changes.  Closing in favour of more specific issues.

issues.title: Cite upcoming IAB output
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
There was discussion of a statement or RFC that says "if you network it, it will be networked" or "any networked device should assume the internet threat model" or something along those lines.  That would be a valuable citation in the context of the applicability statement.

There are many cases where people believe that their network won't end up connected to the Internet.  They make assumptions on that basis and are eventually disappointed to find that there are pressures to become networked (or someone does it for them, see also "SSL added and removed here").  At that point, assumptions about security become invalid and bad things happen.

Here, the point is that the scope of potential use might not be as constrained as imagined.  So if someone thought that these considerations don't apply because of a narrow deployment context, that might not hold true forever.  This is less serious than the security thing, but certainly worth a caution.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: This never manifested, so it doesn't make sense to keep the issue.

issues.title: Mix of core and extensions
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
From Wes:

> do we want to mention that the success of headers functionally is because there is a mix of both protocol specific fields and extra meta data; IE, allowing users and developers to specify new fields that will never be part of the protocol makes the fields be understood

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
In reviewing this, the HTTP community are not in agreement on the relative value gained by intermixing protocol extensions and content metadata.  Several proposals have been made to remove this entanglement.

It is possible that the shared pool has allowed each to benefit from active use from the other, but as both aspects of the protocol are routinely extended my sense is that this is not a major contributing factor.

issues.title: link to ourself
issues.author: kaduk
issues.body: The published Internet-Draft should have a link to the github repo where the document is being maintained.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Fixed in ae5661e

issues.title: examples of invariants helping?
issues.author: kaduk
issues.body: On the face of it, explicitly saying "these are the invariants" ought to imply that everything not listed is subject to change.  Have we been specifying invariants anywhere for long enough to know whether this naive expectation actually holds?

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Welcome to the experiment.  I'm not aware of any attempts at the level we're attempting in QUIC (and I guess TLS to a lesser degree).  I've seen other protocols with less distinct versions of this text, but it's hard to know to what extent that has been successful as it is less obvious.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: We do have older examples, as being cited #63

issues.title: Version negotiation
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
@tfpauly identified a pattern that is useful for version negotiation: rather than build a mechanism that won't be used until v2, hoist the negotiation out of the protocol to the next layer down.  That way you can take advantage of the extension mechanisms at that layer seeing more use (and therefore gaining use-it-or-lose it advantages).

Add a new section specifically about version negotiation in the design principles section.

See also IPv6 Ethertype, ALPN, https://github.com/intarchboard/edm/issues/8

It might also be worth pointing to https://eprint.iacr.org/2016/072

issues.title: Correct or fail
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
One of the nice innovations in the design of TLS 1.3 was the inclusion of mechanisms that ensured that correct implementation of a feature was necessary for interoperation.  Including mention of this in the "dependency" chapter would be great.  The key element here is creating a mechanism where defection by one entity results in changes to keys, and so a mistake in implementation would result in an inability to communicate.

I can't recall the specific mechanism, but the QUIC Initial encryption is an example of this.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: The more I think about this, the less enthusiastic I am about including it.  It feels like a digression into other areas of protocol design.  These tricks are intended to ensure that both peers agree by encoding that agreement into functions that are critical to protocol operation, like the derivation of encryption keys or the TLS finished.  We've learned that these tricks can be useful and can even improve protocol efficiency by allowing validation of agreement without exchanging data (see the QUIC Retry authentication), but they don't necessarily apply to the central theme of this draft.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
I think this may still be relevant to include this point in some form, although I agree with your assessment that it may not be appropriate as a top-level argument.

If we're discussing how version negotiation is particularly prone to ossification, a recommendation that comes out of that is that it can be done in some other protocol's extension layer (ALPN, as the primary example). It would be good to point out at this moment that the mechanism selected for doing version negotiation really ought to be one that has integrity checks and authentication (like how TLS folds in the transcript hash) rather than a useful extension mechanism that could lead to downgrade attacks.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: I'd be interested to see how you might fit something like that in.  I appreciate that the interaction of downgrade protection with version negotiation makes it more challenging than otherwise (see QUIC discussions), but I'm still concerned that it would end up being a digression rather than contributing to the central theme.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Not to be included in the doc, based on discussion.

issues.title: Discuss coordination as a strategy for active use and greasing
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body: In our December EDM call, we discussed how coordination is actually more important than greasing overall as a strategy for active use. This topic should be brought up and discussed in the document.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: This should be more general EDM

issues.title: Discuss greasing as an addition to an existing protocol, versus being part of it from the start
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body: We may want to consider the distinction between trying to add greasing to an existing protocol (TLS, HTTP) versus adding it from the start (QUIC).

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body: The doc doesn't distinguish between adding GREASE at the start (e.g. QUIC) vs retrofitting it (e.g. TLS). Perhaps we should mention that it is useful in both cases. An important property here is that we need the joint to get exercised periodically: adding a new extension every so often works, and GREASE allows us to artificially increasing the cadence in cases where it isn't exercised. It's also possible to force this cadence by coordinating and evolving protocols periodically (e.g. minting a new QUIC version number every 6 months that is the same as QUICv1).

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: See #42.  It doesn't do all of the above, but it might help.

issues.title: Provide an example for cases where an extension mechanism is mandatory but not used
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
Can we provide an example for this text?

Caution is advised to avoid assuming that building a dependency on an extension
mechanism is sufficient to ensure availability of that mechanism in the long
term.  If the set of possible uses is narrowly constrained and deployments do
not change over time, implementations might not see new variations or assume a
narrower interpretation of what is possible.  Those implementations might still
exhibit errors when presented with new variations.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Stephen had a good example of the must-understand extensions in X.509 that might work.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
TLS signature algorithms were a finite enough set that didn't have changes that made extending it very difficult, as one example.

We can also back-reference to the "examples of disuse" section here.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Pointing to the TLS version problem as an example of where implementations required a narrow set would be good.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: We have the IP version stuff already.  Would that be a better example?

comments.author: fluffy
comments.body: SIP messages start with "SIP/2.0" - Good Luck with changing that 2.0 to anything else and having anything useful happen

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: We've moved most examples to the appendix, closing this.

issues.title: Unify sections on disuse?
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
There are currently two sections that cover roughly the same point, with separate examples. It seems odd to have one in section 2, and one in section 3. Can 3.3 be merged into 2.2?

2.2. Examples of Disuse

3.3. Unused Extension Points Become Unusable

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: We can fold the "positive" bits of 3.3 back into 3.2, and move the "negative" examples from 3.3. into 2.2.

issues.title: Can we provide guidelines for frequency of active use?
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
The section on Active Use currently says:

There are currently no firm
guidelines for new protocol development.

Can we do a bit better here to define some principles about how deployment timings and evolution should relate to the use of extension points? Or does that become a separate document?

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Might be worth leaving out of scope.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: The solution is out of scope, but we can look at rewording to say "more experimentation needs to be done", or that it would be useful to figure out the cadence that is required for active use of a given protocol to help it not ossify.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Tommy, if you can suggest a different sentence, that would be good.

comments.author: fluffy
comments.body:
I think we should remove  "There are currently no firm guidelines for new protocol
   development."  A document like this is never going to be able to give hard guidelines on this or any of the other section which are equally vague on how to achieve the goals. The goals are clearly stated here - no need to do more.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Yeah, I'll just remove the sentence.

issues.title: Describe greasing in QUIC
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body: Current text is only TLS, we should add QUIC

issues.title: Threat model
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
There's a lot of great material in this document, but I think one thing that's missing is the threat model. I think this was discussed on a prior call, but consider the following two types of TLS examples:

1. PQ key shares in an extension: in practice, we're primarily concerned with whether or not larger flights will make it through the network. The adversary is not an active attacker, but a benign, possibly buggy middlebox. Greasing to exercise size limits on TLS flights seems like a way to test this in practice.
2. ECH: in practice, we're primarily concerned with whether passive or active middleboxes will tamper with or otherwise block connections using this extension. Greasing _might_ also apply here, but it's less clear than the above example.

In general, the threat model here seems to be more in line with (1). The syntax (wire image) of a protocol might trigger certain middlebox or endpoint behavior that is undesired, and so greasing to avoid these seems generally good. In contrast, (2) modifies both the syntax _and_, in way, the semantics of the protocol. Greasing in the spirit of this draft doesn't seem immediately applicable. 

If it would be useful, I can try and contribute some text to clarify the desired threat model.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
Useful: yes; easy: no.

To start with, I think that the ECH greasing is not entirely in scope here.  Part of that is related to the threat model, where we are considering adversaries of varying levels of sophistication and motivation who might want to block, disrupt, or undermine ECH deployment.  That's a little beyond the scope of this document I think.

The PQ thing is twofold: it's a performance optimization problem (handshakes that span multiple packets, exceeding congestion windows or anti-amplification limits), and a problem where implementations choke on big messages.  I suspect that the former is worse than the latter, but I have no direct information.

The main thing this draft attempts to address is the potential for neglect or laziness to stymie attempts to evolve protocols.  The goal is to capture all the natural pressures on implementations that might lead to ossifying choices.  This includes economy of implementation and various security-based things.  Aside from outright bugs, we are talking about implementations deliberately building features that constrain or prevent protocol evolution.  

So the threat model here is an actor that is either ignorant of or sufficiently insulated from the effects of ossification.  Nothing in the document - except perhaps from the encryption bit - is effective against a deliberate attempt to prevent protocol evolution.

ECH definitely has a threat model that is a superset of this on that basis.

PQ might fit if we're just talking about bugs, but it might just be running into limits of what is fair game for standardization if we are talking about the performance aspects.  If you look at QUIC, the limits of standardization are clear: we could say "all networks MUST support UDP", but that won't stop networks from choosing to block UDP.  We can change the cost-benefit analysis by making QUIC support more or less attractive, but we can't take that choice away altogether.

comments.author: fluffy
comments.body: If protocols had clear Invariants, firewalls would be more likely to enforce theses that make up their own view of things they think are invariants that are not. For example, SIP does not specify a max length for a a header field value so many firewalls make up their own limits and that impacts future use of new larger values.

issues.title: Codepoint reclaim is difficult if negotiation with every node is needed
issues.author: jariarkko
issues.body:
The current draft says:

"Codepoints that are reserved for future use can be especially problematic. Reserving codepoints without attributing semantics to their use can result in diverse or conflicting semantics being attributed without any hope of interoperability. An example of this is the "class E" address space in IPv4 {{?RFC0988}}, which was reserved without assigning any semantics. For protocols that can use negotiation to attribute semantics to codepoints, it is possible that unused codepoints can be reclaimed for active use, though this requires that the negotiation include all protocol participants."

This is valid of course. The text is good as is. However, it might be useful to point out that reclaiming in class E type cases is difficult, because you'd have to negotiate with everyone on the path, as otherwise the intervening routers may discard packets that seemingly use wrong kind of addresses. Or clarify that the latter part of the paragraph applies only to actually *unused* codepoints, whereas *reserved-but-unused* has likely lead to code that prohibits the use.

E.g., one could add this text to the end of the paragraph: "This is in practice impossible in situations such as those involving class E addresses, as all protocol participants would have to include every node along the path."

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Or maybe just "...which includes every node on the path"

issues.title: Consider restructuring section 4
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
Consider grouping as:

Active Use
- Extensions
- Version Negotiation (active use of the layer that contains you)
- Filler/grease

Other
- Crypto
- Invariants
- Feedback

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Or break out feedback into it's own.. don't call this "other".

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
I would say instead:

* Active Use (with the content from the section lifted up into the top of the section)
  * Version Negotiation (as active use)
  * Faking Active Use
* Supplementary Defensive Techniques (it's not *literally* "Other"; but I would be happy to get better suggestions; framing would be that these - in addition to active use - might help)
  * Crypto
  * Invariants
  * Feedback

I realize that this structure has its own shortcomings, but one thing that is nice is that it doesn't require a whole lot of rewriting to get to this point.

issues.title: EDNS Flag Day
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: This was broadly successful, maybe this can be used as an example of where the Robustness Principle was applied over many years and did result in cruft.  The flag day ended that.  Presentation at RIPE and at last IETF.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: After looking into this, the flag day is more applicable to the use-it-or-lose-it draft.  It is an unusual case where the EDNS extension has successfully been used over many years, but intolerance of it had prevented true reliance on it.  That it took ~20 years from the original definition to the point where people were confident in relying on it makes this a good example of what it takes to restore extensibility.

issues.title: ideas to make the document more crisp and shorter
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body:
The message of the document is rather easy and I think it would help to convey this message more clearly if the document would be shorter (also more crisp and less redundant maybe). Here are some proposals:

1) I find the intro text in section 2 rather long and the content of 2.1. more strong to start with and then maybe cut the intro text to:

"Bugs in how new codepoints or extensions can manifest as abrupt termination of sessions, errors, crashes, or disappearances of endpoints and timeouts. These interoperability problems can hinder or stop deployment of new, valuable features even if the negative reactions happen infrequently or only under relatively rare conditions. Fixing bugs
that limit interoperability involves a difficult process that includes identifying the cause of these errors, finding the responsible implementation(s), coordinating a bug fix and release plan, contacting users and/or the operator of affected services, and waiting for the fix to be deployed. Especially for protocols involving multiple parties or that are considered critical infrastructure (e.g., IP, BGP, DNS, or TLS), it could even be necessary to come up with a new protocol design that uses a different method to achieve the same result."

2) I would move the examples in 2.2. to the appendix and maybe only keep this paragraph (of the TLS section):

"Even where extension points have multiple valid values, if the set of permitted values does not change over time, there is still a risk that new values are not tolerated by existing implementations. If the set of values for a particular field remains fixed over a long period, some implementations might not correctly handle a new value when it is introduced. For example, implementations of TLS broke when new values of the signature_algorithms extension were introduced."

3) In section 2.3 the part about MPTCP and TCP Open could also go to the appendix (and maybe provide a bit more insights there).

4) maybe 3.1 could also go to the appendix; also because the last two paragraphs in 3.1. are really redundant with the intro of section 3.

5) I know we just shuffled this around but I guess section 3.2 and 3.3 could also be subsections of 4. I'm actually not quite sure what the purpose or message of section 3 is...?

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: I've tried to enact some of this advice, which I think is timely.  Take a look and see what you think about the changes.  If they help, then I'll take them and we can iterate on the rest of this.  I've left some of the suggestions unimplemented, but I think that tightening things up more would be good.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Moving content to appendix helped a lot here.

issues.title: The connection between active use and invariant could be more clear
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: For me there is this relation between invariants and active use/greasing, that every you don't use actively risks to become an invariant over time and cannot be changed anymore. (Similarly as rfc8558 says that everything that is exposed might be used as path signal and ossify). If people agree, maybe we can make this point more clearly and prominently?

issues.title: Presence and order matter
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
The document talks a lot about how active use of extensions is good practice. Should it also encourage how those used extensions are expressed on the wire? As an example, the order in which TLS extensions appear in a ClientHello are often hard-coded for simplicity. Many implementations simply iterate over the fixed list of extensions, adding them as needed. 

However, it's certainly possible for the _order_ to be a point of ossification. (See [this BoringSSL change](https://boringssl-review.googlesource.com/c/boringssl/+/48045), which acknowledges this fact and allows one to permute the order to change how these extensions are ordered on the wire.) Changing the order would hedge against that ossification. Altering the order may have other side effects, such as performance (though nothing specific comes to mind). 

Should the draft touch on this? If so, I can try and send a PR.

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body: I think this is a great idea!

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
So I don't want to get TOO far down this rabbit hole, but it might be good to use extension ordering as an illustrative example.  If nothing else, it's worth noting that there are sometimes surprising aspects of a design that can ossify.

Two data points here:

Our QUIC implementation uses the natural iteration order of a Rust HashMap, which ends up producing transport parameters in a different order each time it is invoked.  Rust does this randomization to avoid hash stacking attacks.  This wasn't deliberate on our part, as we don't care about those attacks, but I quite like that aspect of it.

Yes, in TLS, some stacks fixated on SNI being the first extension.  Others exploded if the last extension was empty.  There might be other similar things, but those are the ones I'm aware of.  I see that BoringSSL now greases ahead of the first extension, so maybe the first requirement is long expired.

issues.title: More analysis needed
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
The following text:
>RFC 6709 {{?EXTENSIBILITY=RFC6709}} contains a great deal of well-considered
advice on designing for extension.  It includes the following advice:

>> This means that, to be useful, a protocol version-negotiation mechanism
  should be simple enough that it can reasonably be assumed that all the
  implementers of the first protocol version at least managed to implement the
  version-negotiation mechanism correctly.

>This has proven to be insufficient in practice. 

This isn't true for a great many protocols.  Two good examples are HTTP and SMTP.  SMTP has survived **no** versioning mechanism, initially, and now has a retrofitted capabilities mechanism.  There are absolutely invariants in the protocol - you can't just start speaking ebcdic at it.  When an invariant is violated, a new protocol is needed. Stewart Bryant observed this quite some time ago in RFC 5704.

I would reform the point along those lines.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
Hmm, I think that you will find that HTTP is a great example of something that supports this argument as it relates to versioning.  The [upgrade](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2616#section-14.42) mechanism that HTTP defined has is basically a total failure and version indicators have proven to be equally unreliable for other purposes.

Another MIME protocol, SIP, has a versioning system that is universally acknowledged as being functionally unusable.

As for SMTP, I'm not sufficiently familiar to say.  Is the argument that the system for extending the protocol was sufficient to allow for evolution, or is it just that the insufficiency hasn't prevented workarounds from being developed?

(BTW, I think that the invariants exercise is valuable, if only to make it clear when a change to protocol X means that the resulting thing is no longer protocol X.  You remind me that it is probably worth citing Section 2.2 of RFC 5704; the discussion there would enrich the invariants treatment in this document.)

comments.author: elear
comments.body:
SMTP has perhaps the most interesting history here.  MIME along with an encoding header arose as a means to obviate incompatible changes to support transmission of other than ASCII.  But the extension mechanism to SMTP was really not about MIME, but "EHLO", which initiates a capabilities exchange, the most basic of which is, "do you support EHLO?"  Any other new capabilities are introduced through that statement, and can similarly be retired if they are shown not to be useful.  To "lose it" just means to stop advertising the capability.  The base issue for this draft is when to lose it.  Really Pete Resnick, Ned Freed, and Nathanial Borenstein deserve a medal for this sort of elegance (not to mention that MIME is the basis of all web content).

HTTP lacks such a mechanism.  So long as the server simply rejects unknown methods, a client can at prod and poke without causing harm.

It may be worth pursuing why SIP is so hard to upgrade.  I know very little about that protocol.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: BTW, I agree that the version mechanism in HTTP is useless.  It is also harmless.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: EDM: We should soften this claim to not say that it's proven insufficient, but that there are some cases where it has not been sufficient.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: You might actually want to use SMTP as a positive example, and then suggest greasing the EHLO command,

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: The language softening was done with 76c21f4992498d5f99619e552c8646b19e9dd8c7

issues.title: Multi-Party Interactions and Middleboxes {#middleboxes} superfluous to your point
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
As this section is written, it is not about "use it or lose it" but about the need for multiple parties to adopt capabilities before they can be used.  That's true, but the analysis here is both facile and superfluous.  It's superfluous to the point made in the abstract.  It's facile because those middleboxes serve an often necessary function.  I propose that you not get into that discussion here.  If you want to go there, a clearer understanding of the function of a middlebox is important.  At the IP layer, every router is either a middlebox or a participant.

This is another reason to limit recommendations to the higher layers more explicitly.

issues.title: Reframe "cryptography" section as being about boundaries
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body: Instead of just crypto, we're really talking about limiting/controlling participation via a boundary. Cryptography is a good technique here, but there may be others.

issues.title: Abstract should be more descriptive of content
issues.author: elear
issues.body: The abstract doesn't actually say what the doc is going to cover.  I have a PR ready to go to help this.

issues.title: "extension point" needs a definition
issues.author: elear
issues.body: The draft liberally uses the term "extension point".  Having a definition seems I have a PR for this, but I think it might need a touch up or two, and the placement might not be perfect.

issues.title: Section 2: Reword para?
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
The draft currently contains the following paragraph:

> Interoperability with other implementations is usually highly valued, so
deploying mechanisms that trigger adverse reactions can be untenable.  Where
interoperability is a competitive advantage, this is true even if problems are
infrequent or only occur under relatively rare conditions.

This is a bit opaque.  Might I suggest the following reword:

> Protocols generally require the backward compatibility necessary for implementations to properly interoperate.  

But perhaps that doesn't cover the thrust you intend?

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
This might be made clearer.  The point it makes is that interoperability is valuable (but that is basically a non-statement).  The key is that the degree to which interoperability failures can be tolerated can be exceedingly small.  In the web context, something that affects one in a thousand times people can cause something to be completely non-viable.  People do thousands of things, so it could mean that an event at millions to one odds can totally block deployment of a new capability.

In other words, it can be surprising just how small an interoperability risk can be before it affects our ability to deploy something.

issues.title: Appendex A.1: BGP
issues.author: elear
issues.body:
There's not enough information to understand what happened and how this draft pertains to addressing the BGP failure.  For one thing, the reference [RIPE-99] has a reference to a Cisco URL that apparently no longer exists; IOS-XR at that time was brand spanking new.  And it's not like BGP extensions weren't a regular thing at that time.

However, there is a different use case that might be interesting to pursue: partial deployment of ROAs  and S*BGP led to some unintended consequences.  See [Lychev, Goldberg, Shapira](https://arxiv.org/abs/1307.2690).  This gets into multiparty aspects.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
As an example, I think that this is sufficient.  Bad link notwithstanding... (see <https://www.w3.org/Provider/Style/URI.html>).

This isn't saying that the problem is constant or that BGP can't change, but that BGP, like many other protocols, has experienced the same sorts of issues too.

I read the paper; it's good work, but I'm not seeing the relevance.  It is primarily about deployment incentives and how various amounts of deployment might contribute to security goals.

comments.author: elear
comments.body: The issue with BGP is that changes to one router's routing table can impact an entire system.  And so protocol options used between two routers can have an impact beyond those two routers.  I am suspecting what you are seeing is a bug of that variety.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: I've dropped the BGP example.  As you noted privately, it doesn't really support any particular advice in the document, it just existed and that's bloat.

issues.title: Section A.4: IP
issues.author: elear
issues.body: I think it would be better if you mentioned which address space by prefix you are referring to.  For example, 240/4 versus 224/4.  A citation about the confusion you are referring to might also help

comments.author: elear
comments.body: You might also want to talk about how ICMP is **intended** as feedback, but there are some pitfalls, especially when there are bad actors around.

comments.body: I appreciate the point about structure here, but it's not particularly easy to throw everything up in the air and start over.  If you have some ideas about how to move toward a better structure, I can try to shuffle things around a little.

Not sure I really understand what you want to say here. When you talk about implementations, is that endpoint implementations or any implementation that may interact with the protocol? For me documenting invariants was not really intended to guide implementation (so far) but rather have an explicit step in the design of a protocol.
I took another spin at this.  Let me know if this is better.

pulls.title: Protocol design changes
pulls.author: hardaker
pulls.body: Here are some suggested additions and a few edits to the protocol design section.

reviews.author: martinthomson
reviews.body:
Nice additions!

A few typos here and suggestions.

comments.body:
I don't think that this is necessary.

Though it is perhaps true that a good design can be sufficient, the premise/myth that this addresses is that good design is *always* sufficient.  On that basis, it would be sufficient to provide one counter-example.

```suggestion
deployment of a protocol.  Race-to-market attitudes frequently result in an
```

... but I think that there is a different way to state this:

> Market pressures that value timely deployment tend to incentivize development of basic interoperable functions over extension and version negotiation mechanisms.

```suggestion
unparseable and an authentication message are treated the same way by
```

```suggestion
what the protocol specifies should have done: dropped it from being
```
This doesn't really cover all the reasons.  Spoofing can be "helpful", or it can be used to enforce policy as well.  Maybe the right thing to do here is to stop after "many middleboxes".

```suggestion
spoofing of DNS records by many middleboxes.
```

Market pressures that value timely and rapid deployment tend to incentivize development of the most needed interoperable functions over less frequently used extensions and error checking, such as in version negotiation mechanisms?

I was trying to give an example that the reader would understand and latch on to as an example.  One of the issues I'm trying to address in many of my changes is to introduce specific examples, rather than references to protocols that they may not know the details of.  But your point is valid that it's not the only case.  How about s/to inject/such as those that inject/
SGTM
changed
out of date
How about "is not itself sufficient"?

pulls.title: We're not talking about policy; mostly
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This is a hard needle to thread because policy controls are sometimes
unwanted or unexpected and that's not strictly positive.  Making a point
about exposure to unwanted or unexpected policy controls is part of the
message, but we also need to allow endpoints to make a deliberate choice
not to pass something.  I think that I managed that here, the SIP SBC
example is particularly good for that.

I'll follow up with some text on IP router alerts.

pulls.title: Take a better swing at class E
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This adds a shade more nuance to the text, identifies the space and acknowledges the limited reclamation of 224/4.

I might speculate that the limited deployment scope of multicast has allowed the use of 224/4 to continue without widespread problems.  In comparison, attempts to use 240/4 for unicast are much more likely to encounter issues.  Anyone who uses that space for their own address would risk not being able to reach (or not being reachable from) a number of other hosts, even if the routing system accepted the route.

Closes #73.  Not completely; the ICMP feedback is useful, but I don't think that it is necessary to get into that level of detail.

comments.body:
"or not" sounds weird here...

```suggestion
in multicast (224/4), but otherwise has not been successfully reclaimed for any purpose (240/4)
```

reviews.author: DavidSchinazi
reviews.body: I like this, and second Tommy's suggestion

pulls.title: Stronger disclaimer
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
Joel Halpern suggested that we more forcibly disclaim some of the
techniques that are mentioned in the document.

On review, the GREASE section is clear enough about limited
applicability (and also efficacy), so I think we're OK there.  But
the disclaimer in the introduction could be tightened more.

Joel acknowledged that the problem exists, but that the tradeoffs
involved in applying various techniques are much more complex.  That's a
good angle on this.  I've tried to phrase that sentiment in my own
words.
